awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: An Evaluation of the Social Effects of Transportation Infrastructure
awd_abstract_narration:
This doctoral dissertation research project will examine the civic and political effects of two public transportation systems on efforts to deal with issues related to urban fragmentation.  The research project will provide new insights regarding how urban designers and planners understand the built-environment technologies they develop and deploy and how the everyday politics of infrastructural use are based on different sets of motivations.  The project will assess the viability of transportation projects as technological solutions to problems of urban fragmentation, providing new perspectives on an issues evident in cities in both developing and developed nations, including the U.S.  Because the project will directly engage planners, designers, and engineers, it should assist in identifying and sharing "best practices" to improve the evaluation techniques they employ when designing new systems.  As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award also will provide support to enable a promising student to establish a strong independent research career.

Under the guidance of Prof Bruce P. Braun, doctoral student Laura Cesafsky will conduct this project through a detailed examination of the two public transportation systems built in Bogota, Colombia, in the early 2000s:  a "gold standard" bus rapid transit system and an expansive network of separated bicycleways.  The student will gather data regarding system use as well as information from, interviews, focus groups, participant observation, and archival research to evaluate the history of these systems' funding, repair, and management as well as the public controversies they have engendered

por.por_cntn:
The NSF Doctoral Dissertation Fellowship supported 11 months of field research in Bogotá, Colombia. The research looks at the traffic problem in Bogotá and two transportation projects the city implemented in 2000 to manage it. These projects are TransMilenio, the world’s first large-scale bus rapid transit system, and “las ciclorutas,” an expansive bicycle network. These projects were imagined in urban design to create social inclusion and cohesion, and Bogotá became a star city of global urban design. The social objectives of the project, however, were not achieved. The project tries to understand why and to outline the true effects of the systems on social life in Bogotá.

The research produced new and transferable knowledge in three areas: 1) how urban designers and planners understand the built environment technologies they develop and deploy 2) how transportation infrastructure in cities is lived and perceived 3) the viability of transportation projects as technological solutions to problems of social disintegration in Latin America. 1: The research showed that urban design practice, in particular, tended to view transportation networks as "integrative" because they deployed a reason based on form rather than thinking of these as complex and changeable sociotechnical objects. 2: The research found that transportation systems can change in terms of how they are used and perceived, and therefore predictions that such systems will "unify" or "fracture" a polity is built on a false imagination of the nature of technological systems. 3: We found that new transportation projects might produce social cohesion, but they are by no means guaranteed to do so, especially if attention is not paid to their implementation, maintenance and governance. 

Our research benefits society by building links between the academy and industry, and by evaluating empirically uncertain ideas about the social effects of new transportation that are informing that actual ways that cities are being built. We are currently working to broaden the impact of our work—in the short and in the long term—by participating in conferences and cross-institutional fora that are evaluating global urban development “best practices.” 

We have published our results in two online blogs/magazines on global urban issues that each reach a broad, non-academic audience. Co-PI Cesafsky also presented aspects of the research at an open fora a university in Bogotá, and will continue to present the research in the United States and develop publications. The Co-PI will also be returning to Bogotá this year for several months, and plans to dissemante the research broadly among the public, through talks and collaborations with our research affiiliate, Geografía Urbana.
